text: Job Continues His Final Speech
Then\f + \fr 27:1 \ft Hebrew “And” \f* Job again took up his discourse and said,
“⸤As God lives⸥,\f + \fr 27:2 \ft Literally “The life of God” \f* he has removed my justice,
and Shaddai has made my inner self\f + \fr 27:2 \ft Or “soul” \f* bitter.
For ⸤as long as⸥\f + \fr 27:3 \ft Literally “all of still” \f* my breath \add is\add* in me,
and the spirit of God \add is\add* in my nose,
my lips surely will not speak falseness,
and my tongue surely will not utter deceit.
Far be it from me that ⸤I would say that you\f + \fr 27:5 \ft Plural \f* are right⸥;\f + \fr 27:5 \ft Literally “I would declare you as in the right” \f*
until I pass away, I will not put away from me my blamelessness.
I hold fast to my righteousness, and I will not let it go;
my heart will not blame \add any\add* of my days.
“Let my enemy be like \add the\add* wicked
and my opponent like \add the\add* unrighteous,
for what \add is the\add* hope of \add the\add* godless when he cuts \add them\add* off,
when God takes away his life?
Will God hear his cry of distress
when distress comes upon him?
Or, in Shaddai will he find delight?
Will he call upon God at all times?
“I will teach you\f + \fr 27:11 \ft Plural \f* about\f + \fr 27:11 \ft Or “concerning” \f* God’s hand;
I will not conceal that \add which is\add* with Shaddai.
Look, you all have seen,
and ⸤why in the world⸥\f + \fr 27:12 \ft Literally “why this” \f* ⸤have you become altogether vain⸥?\f + \fr 27:12 \ft Literally “vain you have become vain” \f*
“This \add is the\add* portion of \add the\add* wicked human being with God,
and they receive from Shaddai \add the\add* inheritance of \add the\add* ruthless.
If their children multiply, \add it is\add* for \add the\add* sword,
and his offspring ⸤do not have enough to eat⸥.\f + \fr 27:14 \ft Literally “they are not satisfied with bread” \f*
Their\f + \fr 27:15 \ft Hebrew “His” \f* survivors are buried through\f + \fr 27:15 \ft Or “because of” \f* the plague,
and their\f + \fr 27:15 \ft Hebrew “his” \f* widows do not weep.
If he heaps up silver like the dust
and fashions clothing like the clay,
he makes \add it\add* ready, and \add the\add* righteous will wear \add it\add*,
and \add the\add* innocent will divide \add the\add* silver.
“He builds his house like the moth,
and like a booth \add that\add* a watchman has made.
He goes to bed \add with\add* wealth, but\f + \fr 27:19 \ft Hebrew “and” \f* ⸤he will do so no more⸥;\f + \fr 27:19 \ft Literally “he will not do again” \f*
he opens his eyes, and ⸤it is gone⸥.\f + \fr 27:19 \ft Literally “it is not” \f*
Terrors overtake him like the water;
a storm wind carries him off \add in the\add* night.
\add The\add* east wind lifts him up, and he is gone,
and it sweeps him away from his place.
And it hurls at him, and it has no compassion;
he will quickly flee from its power.
It claps its hands over him,
and it hisses at him from its place.
